annotation.TEXT: That locked data also contains a Slasher. Once again, not bothering with it, especially since there's very few Slasher chips in the entire game to begin with.

Even though I prefer this stage over Pharaoh Man's, the Snapper viruses are easily some of the most annoying enemies in the game. The kunai they use can block out almost any type of attack, which is made even worse due to most of the Snapper's placements (they're almost always placed on a level below you).

Here we have the Mole virus, a unique enemy that only appears in this stage. The basic process behind this thing is simple enough: It pops up, you hit it, it appears somewhere else, repeat. It only has 10 HP in total, but it only takes 1 damage from all forms of attack. It's also worth noting that a special version of this virus can appear sometimes, which just so happens to drop the most broken chip in the entire game (that however, is for the next episode).

Another thing to mention: Those directories aren't there just to make that "ding!" noise. If you happen to pass through one in the wrong direction, it spawns a high-level Spooky virus each time you do so. On one hand, this could be seen as a good way to farm for Invis-3 chips. On the other hand...the Spooky viruses still aren't worth dealing with in my opinion (especially since the versions found here can heal themselves for 150 HP).

Despite having the most HP out of any boss in the game (not counting the hidden one), PharaohMan.EXE is actually pretty easy. The main thing to keep in mind with him is that he'll attack every time you hit him, generally by summoning coffins that shoot lasers. The only really threatening move in his arsenal is his poison pharaoh statue. If you don't take it out fast enough, it starts producing shockwaves that cover a large portion of the screen.

Depending on what chips you're using, ShadowMan.EXE can either be one of the easiest or one of the hardest bosses in the game. Considering how mobile he is, ranged chips are a prime choice. Throwing chips and swords, while potentially powerful, will get you into more trouble than anything with this fight.

To explain this area a bit further: It's packed with strong enemies in several tough locations, the most annoying of which are the Ratty and Spooky viruses (and yes, those are their actual names). The former practically infest every corner of this level, and while the Spooky viruses don't show up too much, they're still not worth trying to kill (mainly due to their constant teleporting).

Breaking the usual tradition, we're not actually starting with re-fights this time around (for reference, Zero.EXE is a one time only battle). Instead, let's jump right into the action and progress the story. In order to do so at this point, you need to attempt to enter the Undernet ("attempt" being the key word here, as you'll see).

The second area, the Vacant WWW Comp, is much more straight-forward when compared to Pharaoh Man's level. It focuses more on horizontal progression rather than climbing, though it also has its fair share of strong enemies in certain spots. On a personal note: Aside from Star Man's stage, this level's theme is one of my favorite tracks in the entire game.

Fun fact: This slowdown wasn't a byproduct of processing this video. For whatever reason, this section of the game slows to a crawl. I'm not sure what causes it, but it only happens in this small area with the CanDevil virus and locked mystery data. Immediately after passing it, the game runs at normal speed.

Putting aside the fact that Dex somehow obtained an entry code to a WWW Area, but Higsby (an ex-WWW agent) wasn't able to help us, we now have access to the last two main levels of the game. For now, I'm opting to get the Legendary WWW Area out of the way first. Also, for a bit of reference: Yes, I know there's a locked mystery data above the entrance to this place. I didn't bother getting it because it contained a Slasher chip. While it's a powerful sword, I'd prefer to use my unlockers for stat upgrades at this point.
